You said:
Why are logits called this way?
ChatGPT said:

Ah, “logits” — the term comes straight out of statistics. Let me unpack it:

1. Origin

  • In classical statistics, especially in logistic regression, we often model probabilities ppp using the log-odds:

logit(p)=log⁡p1−p\text{logit}(p) = \log \frac{p}{1-p}logit(p)=log1−pp​

  • This transforms a probability (between 0 and 1) into a number on the real line (−∞,+∞)(-\infty, +\infty)(−∞,+∞).

2. Connection to neural networks

  • In a classification network, the pre-softmax outputs are called logits.

  • Why? Because the softmax is like a multi-class generalization of the logistic function. Each logit ziz_izi​ can be interpreted as the “un-normalized log-odds” of class iii.

  • Softmax turns logits into probabilities:

pi=ezi∑jezjp_i = \frac{e^{z_i}}{\sum_j e^{z_j}}pi​=∑j​ezj​ezi​​

So the logits are the raw scores — they’re not probabilities yet, but they encode relative confidence.

3. Intuitive analogy

Think of logits as the “strength of evidence” for each class. Positive → favor this class, negative → disfavor. Then softmax normalizes that into an actual probability distribution.

In short: logit = log-odds, and in NN jargon, we call pre-softmax outputs “logits” because they generalize this concept.

If you want, I can draw a mini diagram showing logits → softmax → probs → cross-entropy so it’s all visually connected. Do you want me to do that?

You said:
In the line "d = d_after_relu.copy() # avoid mutating caller's buffer" What do you mean by that comment?
ChatGPT said:

Great question — this is a little subtle Python/numpy thing.

When you see:

python
d = d_after_relu.copy()  # avoid mutating caller's buffer

the comment means:

  • If we just wrote d = d_after_relu, then d wouldn’t be a new array. It would just be another reference to the same numpy buffer in memory.

  • Any edits we make to d (like setting some entries to 0) would also silently edit d_after_relu. That could mess up other parts of the code that still need the original data.

By using .copy(), we create a fresh clone of the array, so d and d_after_relu live in different memory. Now we can safely mutate d without side effects.

🔧 Analogy:
Imagine d_after_relu is a shared Google Doc.

  • If you just open it and start typing (d = d_after_relu), you’re editing the same doc, and your changes are seen by everyone.

  • If you make a copy (d = d_after_relu.copy()), you’ve got your own version to scribble on — the original stays intact.

👉 My check for you: why do you think backprop code is especially careful about not mutating buffers from earlier layers?

You said:
I think that in this case it doesn't matter, because d_after_relu is refered to only once during the backpropagation, and then it's changed again only during the next forward pass. So there's not much need to be very careful. But in other situations it can be different.
ChatGPT said:

Exactly — you nailed it.

In a tiny, “from-scratch” implementation where:

  • each layer only passes its gradient once,

  • you immediately overwrite everything on the next forward pass,

…it often doesn’t matter if you mutate the buffer in place.

But in a more complex setup (say PyTorch or TensorFlow):

  • The same intermediate might be needed by multiple downstream branches in the computation graph.

  • Or you might want to inspect saved activations for debugging or visualization.

  • Mutating in place could then break things silently.

That’s why many reference implementations are defensive and .copy(), even if it seems redundant in the simple case.

⚡ Quick quiz for you:
If we removed the .copy() and just did d = d_after_relu, can you think of a concrete debugging situation where you’d later get confused because the original buffer got overwritten?

You said:
Considering that d_after_relu is used to send an output of the previous backprop function grad_max_pool(), then we can lose the ability to output the result of the grad_max_pool(). For example, if we want to see if its output has the desired dimensions, or its output has adequate values in its array.
ChatGPT said:

Yes — that’s exactly the kind of headache I meant.

If you just do d = d_after_relu, then d is just a reference to the same memory. The moment you start zeroing out negative entries (the ReLU gradient mask), you’ve also permanently altered d_after_relu.

So when you later say:

python
print(d_after_relu.shape, d_after_relu)

you’re no longer seeing what came out of grad_max_pool(), but a post-ReLU-gradient version. Debugging turns into a hall of mirrors.

That’s why .copy() is a guardrail — it preserves the “raw” upstream gradient exactly as it arrived.

Want me to walk you through a tiny numeric toy example where you can literally see the difference between “aliasing the buffer” vs “copying it”?

You said:
When we do this, do we get out of the dimensions (boundaries) of the convoluted image? The last choice of the region should choose a region with the dimension i:i+kh, and if i=last pixel of the column of the image, then it should should choose a pixel next to it (that doesn't exist). def grad_conv(image, d_conv_out, kernel_shape): dkernel = np.zeros(kernel_shape) kh, kw = kernel_shape dh, dw = d_conv_out.shape for i in range(dh): for j in range(dw): region = image[i:i+kh, j:j+kw] dkernel += region * d_conv_out[i, j] return dkernel
ChatGPT said:

Ah, nice catch — you’re sniffing around the off-by-one landmines of convolution.

Let’s walk it slowly.

Your grad_conv() is doing the “naive” valid convolution case. That means:

  • Forward pass slid the kernel of shape (kh, kw) over the input image.

  • At each step, it only took fully contained patches.

  • That’s why the output height dh wasn’t h, but (h - kh) + 1. Same logic for width.

So when backprop loops like this:

python
for i in range(dh):
    for j in range(dw):
        region = image[i:i+kh, j:j+kw]

  • On the last iteration, i = dh - 1.

  • But since dh = h - kh + 1, that means i + kh = (h - kh + 1) - 1 + kh = h.

  • Which is exactly the end of the image — no overshoot.

👉 So you never step outside; slicing is safe.

Let me ask you this:
Suppose instead of valid convolution, we used "same" convolution with padding.
What would break in this loop if we didn’t adjust anything?

You said:
If we didn't adjust anything, I think the pudding would be missing. Meaning the random values outside the array would break in. The region variable would contain random variables at the edges of the image, and dkernel would add them to itself too.
ChatGPT said:

I like how you said “the pudding would be missing” — that’s exactly it, the padding is what keeps the kernel sitting comfortably on the edges instead of spilling over into undefined land.

Without padding, in "same" convolution your loop would indeed try to grab:

python
region = image[i:i+kh, j:j+kw]

But now, at the borders:

  • i:i+kh or j:j+kw can poke past the array’s real dimensions.

  • In NumPy, slices that reach too far just truncate, so you’d get a smaller patch instead of random junk.

  • But that smaller patch isn’t what the kernel expects (wrong shape), so your code breaks.

That’s why padding is essential: it ensures every region has the right (kh, kw) shape, even at the edges. Usually zeros are added, but people sometimes use “reflect” or “replicate” padding instead.

👉 Let me throw a check back at you:
If we wanted "same" convolution with zero-padding, what would we need to change in this backprop loop? Would we rewrite the loop, or just prepare the image differently before the loop starts?

You said:
If we use the same convolution with padding (I actually wrote pudding randomly, because I'm not native in English, and both words sound same for me), then we only need to add padding to the image, because the variables dh and dw would already reflect the movement path of the kernel over the image.
ChatGPT said:

Exactly — nice catch (and honestly, I like “pudding” as a nickname for padding, kind of fits).

You’re right:

  • The loop limits range(dh) and range(dw) already line up with the output dimensions.

  • So the only real fix is: pad the input image before entering the loop, usually with np.pad(image, ((pad_h, pad_h), (pad_w, pad_w))).

  • Then every slice image[i:i+kh, j:j+kw] will have the proper (kh, kw) shape, even when the kernel sits at the border.

So in short: the “geometry” of the loop doesn’t change, the environment (padded input) does.

Let me ask you this:
When padding with zeros, what’s the trade-off? Why might zero-padding sometimes hurt feature extraction compared to “reflect” or “replicate” padding?

You said:
I guess the reason is same as when a person looks at the border and thinks "if it's a border because its black, or its a part of the picture that does make sense. If the black color an abstract border of the painting? Is it a space without starts outside? Or just the way to show the borders of the picture? The CNN may guess the same way.
ChatGPT said:

Yes! That’s a really sharp analogy.

When you slap zeros on the edge:

  • The CNN might “hallucinate” strong edges or contrasts that aren’t really there, just because it suddenly sees black bordering the actual content.

  • That’s like a person seeing a black frame and wondering “is that part of the scene, or is that just a boundary artifact?”

With reflect or replicate padding, the border is more consistent with what’s inside the image, so the filters see less artificial contrast.
